metadata.title: More Uncommon Data Cleaners for your Machine or Deep Learning Project | by Bruce H. Cottman, Ph.D. | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: More Uncommon Data Cleaners for your Machine or Deep Learning Project
metadata.description: Almost all paso, including all the functions discussed here, require that paso data cleaning steps (such as removal of Null and NA values) are done already. In our previous projects, we found…

all_paragraphs: Almost all paso, including all the functions discussed here, require that paso data cleaning steps (such as removal of Null and NA values) are done already.
These Data Cleaners are detailed in the article:
In our previous projects, we found ourselves spending the majority of our time cleaning the data with very similar or slightly different data cleaners.

On the first project, we overspent quite a bit in time in data cleaning development. So much so that at the start of the 2nd project, project management had divided data cleaning into three categories: same, less than 33% different, and greater than 33% different.
These categories define two significant reasons:

After two and a half years, we are on our eighth project and find that, so far, less than 1 out of 10 data cleaners fall into that third, more developer-time expensive category. More importantly, our development-to-production time is half of what it was on our first two projects. We can now spend the majority of our time finding a good-enough approach to the machine learning (and sometimes deep learning) solution.
Your experience may be different, as my current domain is fixed-income financial data for asset-allocation, balancing, and risks. (Ok, yes, some other obscure stuff that I won’t mention or use here.)
Now you may ask why I am telling this story. Because as we went down this path, I evolved from a machine learning scientist to a software architect and software engineer.

I now get brought in to fix an in-production service as well as accomplish initial architecture design work and code development. I enjoy going from development to production. Sometimes I get to write and share some of our accomplishments.
I sincerely hope you can use some of our work. All code, for functions used here, can be found at https://github.com/bcottman/paso/toutil.py.
The use of different combinations of cleaning strategies (pipelines) is an important goal of paso.
Discussion will be divided into the following major segments:

The code for this lesson is given in here and here files. The best way to get the entire paso package is to git clone the base. pipwill not work as there are text-based files (descriptions) in this package that you will need.
This function is based on willmcginnis's convert_input().
paso is a package in which all functionality and methods require a pandas DataFrame.

Since paso functions and methods consume only pandas DataFrames, we need a function to transform various python data-types and while also delivering paso’s basic services. This function is paso.to_util.toDataFrame.
This function is the exception to “paso the first argument is a DataFrame “ rule because it transforms a 1-D or 2-D list, tuple, csr_matrix, numpy array, or 1d pandas Series into a pandas DataFrame.
You also have paso.to_util.isDataFrame(X) -> bool to check if the object is or is not a pandas.DataFrame.
If you don't need paso's services, such as logging and caching, you can use the method pandas.DataFrame.I would recommend that you do not do this, but you have the un-pythonic choice to do so.

A good practice is to make your dataset of type DataFrame at the start of your pipeline. Changes by the paso function will be kept in the DataFrame instance's state (inplace=True). In-place will happen though-out the pipeline of your experimental run to maximize the speed of completion and minimize memory usage.
If you need to refer to the original DataFrame, then you can do something similar to this:
However, you are warned that keeping the original is going to consume some of your computer’s memory.
It is up to you to keep around a copy of the original dataset.
Almost always, you input the original from a local file or non-local file addressed by URL, and therefore, you probably do not need to keep a copy in your computer’s memory.
You can see the size of any object in bytes with:
This shows that an empty DataFrame has a size of 24 bytes.
Now, we create an artificial dataset, df_of_ints, a numpy array of ints.
toDataFrame(arr, columns=['a','b']) can specify first two column names, for the new DataFrame.
Notice, how the first two column names were given and toDataFramedetected that and created the next four column names that were needed.
This time we invoke toDataFrame while keeping paso logging off. Logging is only turned off for the scope of the function invoked.
This function transforms any boolean, object, or integer values of a pandas DataFrame instance to category type values.
The exception is continuous (float or datetime) values, which return un-transformed.
If you want to convert continuous or datetime types to a category, then use ContinuoustoCategory or DatetimetoComponents before paso toCategory.
Note: paso data cleaning steps (such as removal of Null and NA values) have been done previous to this step.
datetime features should call toDatetimeComponents() before this step so that datetime components (which are of type int) converts to category.
The behavior of this step is NOT to convert datetime to category.
Looks like df_of_ints is unchanged, which is what we wanted in this case, inplace=False .
Now it looks like all values of df_of_ints are of type int converted to type categorywith inplace=True.
I am guessing some of the readers (not you) are a little bothered by df_of_ints.toCategory(inplace=True). If so, you will be more bothered by this:

If you are not bothered or even puzzled about this fuss, it is because you know that a DataFrame can be a python class instance and you call methods on a class instance. You can even chain methods. That is, you can call one method after another.
In this case, I chained the two methods .toCategory().dtypes off the DataFame instance output by toDataFrame .

All the methods of class Cleaners and functions of toutilsof paso require the 1st argument to be a DataFrame instance. Dataframe as 1st argument enables them to be methods of a DataFrame by using a refactored decorator based on the package pandas-flavor.
Chaining can make it very easy to understand because operations are invoked left to right. That is the same way you read (English and many other languages).
Some people prefer to chain instead of using sklearn’s Pipelines. You will notice how our chaining is slightly different in syntax than sklearn’s Pipeline chaining.
Our chaining is very close to the look-and-feel of R. We will use both invocation methods from now on.
Why would you want to break a datetime into unit components? Well it leads to an advanced encoding tactic, that is discussed in detail in the paper Entity Embeddings of Categorical Variables and

"Categorical variables are known to hide and mask lots of interesting information in a data set and many times they might even be the most important variables in a model. A good data scientist should be capable of handling such variables effectively and efficiently. If you are a smart data scientist, you’d hunt down the categorical variables in the data set, and dig out as much information as you can."
For many reasons, all resulting in better predictive power, you can break a datetime into intcomponents. You can go further and convert datetime int components into categorical-type components.
You probably see where this is going. If I have some non-categorical features, such as a column of datetimes, I will need a function to turn datetime into categorical(s) feature(s).
I will cover how to use categorical features as embedding vectors in an upcoming article.
You can see what datetime components are available with datetimeComponents. Our version is based on a function found in the fast.ai package.
I first create a DataFrame instance to can show what toDatetimeComponents does.
In this case, datetimeComponents transformed each datetime value into thirteen int components. It then transformed those int types into category types.
if X[[dt_features]] is not of datetime type (such as object type) then there IS NO attempt to coerce X[[dt_features]] to datetime type.
It is best if the raw data field is read/input in as datetime rather than object. You can convert a dataframe column to datetime using:

We can put automatic conversion in, but we found for some of our larger datasets (>100 million rows) that conversion was too slow. It is so much faster to start the pipeline with DataFrame columns as datetime rather than object.
toContinuousCategory transforms any continuous float, or integer values of a pandas DataFrame to category values by grouping into bins.
Binning, also known as quantization is used for transforming continuous numeric features (np.number type) into category type.
Each bin represents a range of continuous numeric values.
Specific strategies of binning data include fixed-width (quantile=False) and adaptive binning (quantile = True).
No matter the type of the input dataset it will be returned as DataFrame. If you want to set the feature names, call toDataFrame before this function.

Fixed-width binning only works, WITHOUT SCALING, with datasets for tree-based models such as random forest, xgboost, lightgbm, catboost, etc. Non-tree base models, such as linear, log, SVM, neural nets, etc., won’t work correctly as they depend on the magnitude of values.

Binning increases type I and type II error; (simple proof is that as the number of bins approaches infinity, then information loss approaches zero). Also, changing the number of bins will alter the bin distribution shape unless the distribution is uniformly FLAT.
Quantile binning use with a singular data set.

Transforming a Continuous feature into a Category feature based on percentiles (QUANTILES) is WRONG if you have a train and test data sets. Quantiles are based on the data set and will be different unless each data set distribution shape is the same. In the limit, there are only two bins, and then almost no relationship can be modeled. We are mostly doing a t-test.
if there are nonlinear or even nonmonotonic relationships between features
If you need linear binning, not quantile, use quantile=False .
Despite the above warnings, your use case may require quantile-binning.In that case, apply quantile binning to a merged train and test dataset and then separate them afterward.

Quantile based binning is a reasonably good strategy to use for adaptive binning. Quantiles are specific values or cut-points which partition the continuous-valued distribution of a feature into discrete contiguous bins or intervals. Thus, q-Quantiles partition a numeric attribute into q equal (percentage-width) partitions.
These bins turn into categorical features. You may want to do this for such features as age, weight, temperature, salary, price, etc..

Well-known examples of quantiles include the 2-Quantile, median, divides the data distribution into two equal (percentage-width) bins, 4-Quantiles, standard quartiles, four equal bins (percentage-width) and 10-Quantiles, deciles, ten equal widths (percentage-width) bins.
You should note that the new features were resulting from the quantile-binning append with q while new features resulting from fixed-width-binning append with w.
Tranform continuous float features into category and drop the original columns:
Transform continuous float features into fixed-width category bins and leave the original columns.
Truncate column name to a specific length. If column length is shorter, then column length remains as is.
toColumnNamesFixedLen will truncate all columns to a given length and append a given separator character with the index of duplicate columns, except for the first distinct column name.
In this section. I will show a functional programming style in python. This style is also called chaining and should be very familiar to those who use R.
I am going to create a DataFrame so we can show some of our cleaners in a chain (pipeline).
Starting with Python 3.6 (PEP 484), type hints were introduced. Type hints (note: not strong type checking) make it possible to also do static type checking of Python code with downstream tools.
Using type hints, the toutil function call signatures are summarized:
The code for this article are given here and here.

If you have a service or feature or see a bug, then leave the paso project a note.
I write my blog utilizing decades of experience in investment, programming, and data science.
